newsitem.title: INDIA: India moves anti-corruption bill in parliament.
newsitem.headline: India moves anti-corruption bill in parliament.

text.p: The Indian government on Friday introduced an anti-corruption bill in the lower house of parliament that would set up a watchdog panel to investigate scandals involving parliament deputies and public officials.
It would let the government establish an institution acting as ombudsman to "inquire into allegations of corruption against public functionaries and for matters connected therewith."
The panel would include an ombudsman (Lokpal) and two members appointed for a five-year period. The ombudsman should be a Supreme court judge, the bill said.
India has been rocked by a series of corruption scandals in recent years, including one in which former prime minister P.V. Narasimha Rao and several of his party members have been named.
Federal police have investigated the Rao, 74, in a cheating scandal.
An Indian expatriate, Lakhubhai Pathak, has said he paid $100,000 to Chandraswami, a Hindu holy man and acquaintance of Rao, in a failed attempt to secure a government contract.
Rao has also been in the public eye in connection with a fertiliser import scandal in which one of his sons has been investigated by federal agents. Rao has denied any wrongdoing.

Former communications minister Sukh Ram, a Rao cabinet member, was suspected of involvement in a financial scandal after federal police last month recovered about one million dollars from his residences.

Seven of Rao's ministers and two state governerors resigned in January to face allegations in an $18 million-political bribery scandal after an illegal foreign exchange dealer claimed to have given them money. They all denied wrongdoing.
